required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Placing Preterm Infants in Polyethylene Bags Immediately After Birth
clinical_study.official_title: Placing Preterm Infants in Polyethylene Bags Immediately After Birth

brief_summary.textblock: Primary objective: To determine if placing preterm infants in a polyethylene bag (PB) immediately after birth, before the umbilical cord is clamped, will increase the number of preterm infants with a normal temperature on admission to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU).

detailed_description.textblock:
Newly born preterm infants that develop abnormal temperature after birth have higher morbidity and mortality. Placing infants < 32 weeks' gestation in a polyethylene bag (PB) in the delivery room (DR) reduces the rate of hypothermia on admission to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). Since 2012, the rate of admission hypothermia in preterm infants, placed in a PB in the DR at the National Maternity Hospital (NMH), has increased significantly. This may be as a result of heat loss while the infant remains attached to the cord.
Our primary objective is to determine if placing preterm infants in a PB immediately after birth, before the umbilical cord is clamped will increase the number of preterm infants with a normal temperature on admission to the NICU.

study_design_info.masking_description: In the delivery room, the infant is randomised to application of a polyethylene bag before or after cord clamping. Neither the delivery room care provider nor the investigator are blinded to the group assignment. When the infant is stable, they are be transferred from the delivery room to the neonatal unit. The outcome assessor is the admitting nurse in the neonatal unit who will be blinded to the group assignment.

primary_outcome.measure: Temperature on admission to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU)
primary_outcome.time_frame: The primary outcome measure will be determined on admission to the NICU, before the infant is removed from the transport incubator (< 90minutes of life)
primary_outcome.description: Rectal temperature recorded upon arrival to the NICU, while the infant is in the transport incubator. (measured in degrees celsius)

secondary_outcome.description: Type and duration of respiratory support in the DR

secondary_outcome.measure: External cardiac massage in the delivery room
Infant temperature recordings in the delivery room
secondary_outcome.description: Measured with Microlife MT 1931 digital thermometer at the rectum. Recorded in degrees celsius.

secondary_outcome.measure: Axillary temperature on admission to the NICU
secondary_outcome.description: Measured with Microlife MT 1931 digital thermometer at the rectum. Recorded in degrees celsius.
Measured with Microlife MT 1931 digital thermometer at the rectum. Recorded in degrees celsius.

secondary_outcome.measure: Central catheter placement in first 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Yes/no. Type and location of catheter

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)

secondary_outcome.measure: Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) on the first day of life (24 hours)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Yes/ no, needle aspiration or definitive chest drain or both

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)
Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)
Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)
Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)
Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)
After 72 hours of life until term corrected or hospital discharge (maximum 16 weeks)

secondary_outcome.measure: Oxygen requirement at 36 weeks corrected gestational age

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Term corrected gestation age or hospital discharge (<17 weeks)

arm_group.arm_group_label: PB BCC: Polyethylene Bag Before Cord Clamping
arm_group.description: Immediately after delivery, while still attached to placental circulation, infants will be placed in a PB. After the cord has been clamped and cut, the infant will be transferred to the resuscitaire for ongoing care. In the case of caesarean section a sterile bag will be used and prepared observing sterile techniques. A member of the neonatal team donned in sterile gown and gloves will assist the obstetrician in placing the infant in the PB.

arm_group.arm_group_label: PB ACC: Polyethylene Bag After Cord Clamping
arm_group.description: Infants will not be placed in a PB immediately after birth. After the cord has been clamped and cut, the infant will be transferred to the resuscitaire where they will be placed in a PB.

intervention.intervention_name: Polyethylene bag before the umbilical cord is clamped
intervention.description: 11" x 16" (279mm x 406mm) sterile resealable PB (Resealable Polybag, Helapet Ltd, Bedfordshire, UK)
intervention.arm_group_label: PB BCC: Polyethylene Bag Before Cord Clamping

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Infants who are inborn at the National Maternity Hospital at < 32 (up to 31+6) weeks' gestation by best obstetric estimate will be included in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Infants with a large abdominal wall or neural tube defects
- Infants with an imperforate anus
- Infants to whom resuscitative measures are not initiated in the DR
